articles.title: PREDICTING EARTHQUAKES
articles.summary: This document outlines a detailed schedule of events for an astronomy club across March and April, featuring multiple 'Star Parties' at various state parks, 'General Meetings' with speakers (including one on earthquake predictions from solar and lunar tides), 'Board Meetings,' and 'Introductory Astronomy Classes.' It also announces an 'Annual Bay-Area Astronomical Flea Market and Auction.'

articles.title: PREDICTING EARTHQUAKES
articles.summary: An astronomy club will host a talk by Steve Kilston on March 11, focusing on earthquake prediction techniques. The presentation will explore how the positions of the Sun and Moon, along with their tidal effects on Earth, might influence seismic activity. This topic aims to connect astronomical phenomena with real-world geophysical events.

articles.title: MEW (OLD?) SJAA OFFICERS APPOINTED
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) announced its 1988 officers, including President Tom Ahl, Vice President Paul Mancuso, Secretary Jim Van Nuland, and Treasurer Jack Peterson, at the February Board Meeting. These newly appointed officers are scheduled for official installation at the March 11 General Meeting.

articles.title: DARKNESS SQUANDERING TIME
articles.summary: The article announces the start of Daylight Saving Time on April 2 and details the 1989 Messier Marathon, scheduled for April 1/2-3. Despite a hindering full Moon in March, the event will take place at Fremont Peak and Henry Coe Park, inviting members to join Don Machholz. The ideal observing period is mid-March to early April, aiming for 109 out of 110 Messier objects from the club's latitude.

articles.title: NEW ASTRONOMY ORGANIZATION
articles.summary: The Halls Valley Group, a new astronomy organization within the Friends of Grant Ranch, is hosting public star parties and astronomical lectures at Grant Ranch County Park on first Saturdays of the month. They have acquired a 10-inch telescope and are developing a building to house it, inviting both the general public and the SJAA to attend these events. Dates are expected to change in 1990 to align with new moon phases.

articles.title: FEES AT PUBLIC PARKS
articles.summary: This document clarifies the day-use fees for star parties held at public parks, addressing confusion regarding whether participants are considered 'day use' or 'camping.' Park rangers have agreed that setting up at a car park party site, including sleeping in a vehicle there, qualifies as day use. However, occupying a regular campsite requires paying the standard camping fee, with an exception for officially-scheduled star parties at Henry Coe State Park where attendees are considered public participants.

articles.title: SESSION AND NO FEES APPLY
articles.summary: The document highlights that during a specific 'SESSION', no fees apply for park entry. However, at other times, a $3 day-use fee is enforced, payable via an honor system slot if the office is closed. It emphasizes the importance of paying fees to ensure the park's continued operation and funding.

articles.title: THIRD INSTALLMENT OF ASTRONOMY CLASS - MARCH 18TH
articles.summary: The third installment of the Introductory Amateur Astronomy class is scheduled for March 18th, featuring Dr. Jay Freeman discussing binoculars for celestial observation. Following a successful February session on celestial coordinate systems, future classes will cover diverse topics including constellations, astrophotography, occultation observing, and telescope use, with a planned field trip to Fremont Peak and potential planetarium visits.

articles.title: MARCH STARRY NIGHTS BY: RICHARD STANTON
articles.summary: This article outlines celestial events and observing opportunities for March, including details on minor meteor showers (Corona Australids and Virginids), a partial solar eclipse on March 7th, and a Saturn-Neptune conjunction on March 3rd. It also provides information on an Io transit/shadow event for Jupiter on March 25th, encourages observations of Jupiter's Great Red Spot, and offers a deep sky challenge to locate the Medusa Nebula.

articles.title: BY: DENISE HUTSON
articles.summary: At the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) first General Meeting of 1989, Ron Dere of Lockheed Missiles and Space Company (LMSC) presented an update on Lockheed's involvement in the Space Station Program. The presentation detailed the station's construction, purpose as an orbiting research lab, international collaboration, challenges of long-term space habitation, crew rotation, and its role as a future transportation node for planetary missions like Mars. The article highlights the station's potential to pave the way for human expansion into space.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document, titled "ASTRO ADS," serves as a free classifieds section for non-commercial advertisers to sell astronomically related products and services. It features listings for various used telescopes and accessories, including a Celestron Super C8 plus, an 8-inch f/12 apochromatic refractor, a Sky Sensor Computer Control, and a Celestron LPR filter, along with a request for a used Astroscan and a moving sale for back issues of astronomy magazines.

articles.title: The 9th ANNUAL Bay Area Astronomical Auction
articles.summary: The 9th ANNUAL Bay Area Astronomical Auction, hosted by the San Jose Astronomical Association, is scheduled for Saturday, April 22nd, at the Los Gatos Red Cross building. The event will include a swap-meet in the afternoon, followed by a main auction and a concurrent silent auction for astronomical and telescope-making equipment. Sellers can pre-register items, with a 10% commission on sales benefiting public astronomy education.

articles.title: DIRECTIONS TO THE AUCTION
articles.summary: This document provides directions and pre-registration information for the 1989 Bay Area Astronomical Auction, specifying the location, opening time, and a $1 donation for buyers/sellers. Additionally, it features a comprehensive classifieds section listing various used astronomical equipment for sale, including telescopes (Celestron, Meade, refractors), mounts, accessories, and astronomy magazines. Contact information and prices (or best offer) are provided for each item.

articles.title: THE GREAT RED SPOT OF JUPITER BY: JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: The article reports on observations of Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS), noting its appearance as an orange or pink feature despite recent poor weather. It provides guidance for amateur astronomers, suggesting they look for a large 'dent' in Jupiter's South Equatorial Belt and consult published photos if unsure. The author also mentions predictions for when the GRS will be optimally visible.

articles.title: Great Red Spot on Meridian PST/PDT
articles.summary: This document provides a schedule of dates and times when Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) will transit the meridian, specifically for observers in the PST/PDT time zone. The list covers transits occurring from early March through early April, allowing astronomers to plan their observations of this prominent Jovian feature.

articles.title: SPACE PROGRAM UPDATE BY: BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: This space program update details the delay of Discovery's launch to at least March 12 due to cracked bearing races on oxygen turbopumps, while the first Delta II commercial booster successfully launched a Navstar satellite. Other key developments include the Phobos 2 spacecraft entering Mars orbit, the failure of the GOES-West weather satellite, the completion of the final shuttle solid rocket motor test, and the upcoming delivery of new solar arrays for the Hubble Space Telescope.

articles.title: DOUBLE, TRIPLE AND MULTIPLE STARS BY: PATRICK DONNELLY
articles.summary: The article encourages amateur astronomers to delve deeper into the nature of multiple star systems while observing, using Castor (Alpha Geminorum) as a detailed case study. It describes Castor as a visually resolvable triple system whose components (A, B, and C) are each further revealed to be spectroscopic doubles, making it a spectacular six-star system. The author details the magnitudes, separations, and orbital characteristics of these complex stellar components, encouraging contemplation during observation.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article reports on recent comet activity, including two new discoveries and one recovery, none of which are expected to become very bright. It also reviews comet finds for 1988, noting three visual and one photographic amateur discovery, five by professionals, and five photographic finds by the Solar Max Satellite, which all impacted the sun. The latest Solar Max comet, SSM 7 (1988q), was observed at magnitude -4 before approaching the sun.

articles.title: Sungrazer comet.
articles.summary: This article provides brief updates on several comets, detailing their discovery or recovery dates, current brightness, and orbital status. It covers Comet Bradfield (1984c) which is now dimming, the recovery of Periodic Comet Russell 3 (1989d) which might brighten next year, and two recent discoveries by Carolyn Shoemaker, Comet Shoemaker (1989e) and Comet Shoemaker (1989f), both of which are either dimming or will not get brighter.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article analyzes visual comet discoveries from 1975-1988, correlating them with lunar phases to determine optimal times for comet hunting. It reveals that most comets are found when the Moon is not significantly illuminating the sky, with distinct discovery patterns emerging for morning and evening observations. The author explains how lunar phases affect sky darkness and contrast, influencing where and when comet hunters focus their efforts.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA hosts monthly General Meetings at the Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California. These events feature guest speakers discussing various astronomical topics, equipment, and slide presentations, alongside "Indoor Star Parties" for members to share interests such as astrophotography, deep sky observation, and telescope making. Held on the 1st Saturday of each month, the meetings offer a friendly atmosphere for all astronomy enthusiasts.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Indoor Star Parties are informal Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers to socialize, discuss astronomy, and share equipment. Attendees are encouraged to bring telescopes and accessories, while events may also include astrophotography slideshows or introductory astronomy workshops. The SJAA occasionally holds board meetings concurrently with these events.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) organizes "Star Parties" on Saturdays closest to the New Moon for astronomical observation and astrophotography. Fremont Peak State Park is highlighted as a particularly popular location, drawing many amateur astronomers for serious deep-sky observing. The article also lists contact information for the SJAA's officers and board members and provides directions to Fremont Peak.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing various membership options including standard, junior, and one bundled with a Sky & Telescope subscription. It specifies the corresponding fees and provides instructions for submitting the application and payment to the treasurer either by mail or in person at an SJAA meeting. Contact information for the association's treasurer is also included.
